questions.text: A forceps delivery is being planned for a patient with prolonged second stage of labour. Which of the following is not a prerequisite for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Completely dilated cervix is a prerequisite for forceps delivery. 

Prerequisites for forceps delivery:

  • Experienced operator
  • Engaged head
  • Ruptured membranes
  • Vertex presentation
  • Completely dilated cervix
  • Precisely assessed fetal head position
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion not suspected
  • Absent fetal coagulopathy or bone demineralization disorder

Before operative vaginal delivery, the bladder should be emptied to provide additional pelvic space and minimize bladder trauma.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for the use of the following instrument except:

choices.text: Fetal skull has reached pelvic floor
Fetal head is on the perineum
Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
Rotation of fetal head is more than 45 degrees

questions.solution:
The image shows Wrigley's forceps, which is a type of outlet forceps. Rotation of the fetal head should not exceed 45 degrees for the application of outlet forceps. This is because it increases the risk of vaginal wall lacerations.

Related Pearl: Criteria for forceps delivery

Procedure Criteria
Outlet forceps
  • Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
  • Fetal skull has reached pelvic floor
  • Fetal head is at or on perineum
  • Sagittal suture is in anteroposteriordiameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position
  • Rotation does not exceed 45 degrees
Low forceps Leading point of fetal skull is at station > +2 cm and not on the pelvic floor:
a) Rotation is 45 degrees or less, or
b) Rotation is greater than 45 degrees
Mid forceps Station of fetal head is between 0 and +2 cm.

High forceps

 Not included in classification. Not used anymore.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about instrumental vaginal delivery?

choices.text: Full cervical dilatation is the only prerequisite
Forceps can be used for delivery of the after-coming head  of breech
Ventouse cannot be used in rotational occipitotransverse/ posterior delivery
Engaged head is not a prerequisite

questions.solution:
Forceps can be used for delivery of the aftercoming head of breech. The advantages are as follows:

  • Delivery can be controlled by giving pull directly on the head and the force is not transmitted through the neck.
  • Flexion is better maintained.
  • Mucus can be sucked out from the mouth more effectively.

Prerequisites for instrumental vaginal delivery:

  • Ruptured membranes vertex presentation
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion not suspected
  • No fetal coagulopathy or bone demineralization disorder
  • Completely dilated cervix
  • Precisely assessed fetal head position
  • Engaged head
  • Experienced operator

Note: Ventouse can be used for occipitotranverse or posterior position.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman at 35 weeks of gestation is wheeled into the labour room following the onset of labor. A forceps delivery is planned for her. Which of the following is not a contraindication for this?
questions.solution:
Forceps can be used to deliver a preterm baby where it is believed to form a protective cage. Vacuum is contraindicated in these cases.

Contraindications of forceps delivery:

  • Unengaged head
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion 
  • Malpresentations like brow and face (mentoposterior position)
  • Cervix not completely dilated
  • Inability to define position
  • Fetal coagulopathy or osteogenesis imperfecta

Note: Forceps delivery is only reserved for mentoanterior position.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: What is the given device used for?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a vacuum delivery system. It is used for vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery of the fetus.

Theoretical advantages of ventouse (vacuum extraction) compared to forceps include:

  • Simpler requirements for positioning of the fetal head
  • Avoidance of space occupying blades within the vagina
  • Lower maternal trauma rates

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 woman with a history of mitral valve prolapse was planned for ventouse delivery. Which statement is true regarding the mode of delivery planned for this patient?

choices.text: Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborns are frequently seen
It can be applied when fetal head is above the level of ischial spine
Maternal trauma is seen more frequently when compared to forceps
It cannot be used when fetal head is not fully rotated

questions.solution:
Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborns are more frequently seen with ventouse delivery than with forceps delivery.

Maternal morbidity is seen more with forceps deliveries and perinatal morbidity is seen more with vacuum deliveries.

Maternal morbidity seen in operative vaginal deliveries include:

  • Increased third and fourth-degree vaginal lacerations
  • Pelvic floor disorders
  • Postpartum hemorrhage

Perinatal morbidity seen in operative vaginal deliveries include:   

  • Vacuum-assisted perinatal injuries: Cephalohematoma, subgaleal hemorrhage, retinal hemorrhage, neonatal jaundice secondary to these hemorrhages, shoulder dystocia, clavicular fracture, intracranial hemorrhage, and scalp lacerations. 
  • Forceps-assisted perinatal injuries:  Higher rates of facial nerve injury, brachial plexus injury, depressed skull fracture, and corneal abrasion.  

In cardiac patients, vaginal delivery is preferred. It is conducted with the laboring woman in an upright or left decubitus position. Prophylactic use of vacuum is done to cut short the second stage of labor. This is to minimize aortocaval compression. Caesarean section is not preferred since it is associated with more blood loss and higher thromboembolic and infection risk.

questions.text: Contraindications of ventouse include all except:
questions.solution:
Deep transverse arrest is an indication for ventouse delivery.

In ventouse delivery technique, suction is created within a cup placed on the fetal scalp such that traction on the cup aids fetal expulsion. The important step in ventouse extraction is proper cup placement over the flexion point.

The vacuum is gradually created by increasing the suction in increments of 0.2 kg/cm2 every 2 minutes until a total negative pressure of 0.8 kg/cm2 is reached. Progressive descent should accompany each traction attempt.

Related Pearl: Vacuum delivery- indications and contraindications

Indications of ventouse:    

Therapeutic-

  • Fetal distress in second stage
  • Maternal distress in second stage
  • Prolonged second stage
  • Deep transverse arrest and persistent occipitoposterior
  • High vacuum for second twin

Prophylactic-

  • Preeclampsia
  • VBAC
  • Cardiac defects
  • Anemia

Contraindications of ventouse:     

  • Preterm head
  • Face presentation         
  • Fetal coagulopathy
  • Fetal blood sampling

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the labor room assisting the delivery of a primigravida in labor. The obstetrician planned for a ventouse delivery because of maternal exhaustion. She asked you to help place the ventouse cup. Where would you place it?

choices.text: On the sagittal suture 3 cm in front of posterior fontanelle
On the sagittal suture 3 cm behind of anterior  fontanelle
On the coronal suture 6 cm away from anterior fontanelle

questions.solution:
An important step in vacuum extraction is proper cup placement over the flexion point. It is a point on the sagittal suture that lies 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle.

Advantages of correct positioning of cup in vacuum extraction:

  • Maximum traction
  • Minimum cup detachment
  • Twisting of fetal head is avoided
  • Smallest head diameter is delivered through the pelvic outlet
  • Success rate is improved
  • Fetal scalp injury rates are lowered
  • Perineal trauma is reduced because the smallest fetal head diameter distends the vulva

questions.text: A 24-year-old term primigravida was brought to the hospital in labor. Prophylactic ventouse was used due to ineffective expulsive efforts by the mother. What is the maximum negative pressure used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
The maximum negative pressure used in ventouse is 0.8 kg/cm2 

Gradual vacuum creation is recommended. This is generated by increasing the suction in increments of 0.2 kg/cm2 every 2 minutes. This is done until a total negative pressure of 0.8 kg/cm2 is reached.

This slow incremental approach would allow for a more firm attachment of the vacuum cup to the fetal head and thereby a lower failure rate.

questions.text: A prophylactic ventouse was planned for an anaemic pregnant woman. Delivery through this mode should occur within______.
questions.solution: Delivery with ventouse should occur within 3 pulls over 15-20 min.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida delivered a full-term male baby by assisted forceps delivery. What is not an advantage of this mode of delivery?

choices.text: Quick in case of fetal distress

questions.solution:
Autorotation is seen with vacuum extraction and not assisted forceps delivery.

Advantages of ventouse over forceps:

  • No need of anaesthesia
  • Less expertise required
  • Less maternal injuries
  • Promotes autorotation
  • Does not occupy the sides
  • Less traction force needed

Advantages of forceps over ventouse:

  • No maternal effort is needed
  • Quick in case of fetal distress
  • Can be used in face and breech
  • Can be used in preterm
  • Less cephalohematoma
  • Delivery failure is less

questions.text: What is the advantage of ventouse over forceps?

choices.text: Can be used in preterm head

questions.solution:
The advantage of ventouse over forceps is that less expertise is required in this technique.

Advantages of ventouse over forceps:

  • No need of anaesthesia
  • Less expertise required
  • Less maternal injuries
  • Promotes autorotation
  • Does not occupy the sides
  • Less traction force needed

Advantages of forceps over ventouse:

  • No maternal effort is needed
  • Quick in case of fetal distress
  • Can be used in face and breech
  • Can be used in preterm
  • Less cephalohematoma
  • Delivery failure is less

questions.text: During a routine check-up of a multigravida at 32 weeks of gestation, the fetus was found to be in breech presentation. The obstetrician planned to do an external cephalic version.  What is the ideal time to do this procedure?
questions.solution:
The ideal time to do external cephalic version is 37 weeks. This procedure is attempted in a woman who has completed 36 weeks of gestation and has a breech fetal presentation.

Before 37 weeks, a breech presentation has a high likelihood of correcting spontaneously. Moreover, if performed too early, there is time to return back to breech.

After 37 weeks, the success rates of ECV are very low. Although it can be performed until the early stages of labour, it is not recommended.

questions.text: A 25-year-old multigravida at 36 weeks presents for routine ANC. On examination, a hard, ballotable structure is felt at the fundus. NST is reactive. The obstetrician performs the following procedure on her. When will this procedure be contraindicated?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown here is external cephalic version. A relative contraindication for this procedure is intra-uterine growth restriction.

Related Pearl: External cephalic version- indications and contraindications

External cephalic version (ECV) is done to bring the favourable cephalic pole in the lower pole of the uterus.

Indications:

  • Breech presentation
  • Tranverse lie

Contraindications:

  • APH due to risk of placental separation
  • Fetal causes- hyperextension of the neck ("star-gazing" position), large fetus (>3.5 kg), congenital abnormalities, dead fetus, fetal compromise
  • Obstetric complications- severe pre-eclampsia, obesity, elderly primigravida, bad obstetric history 
  • Rh alloimmunization
  • Multiple pregnancy
  • Ruptured membrane
  • Congenital malformations of uterus
  • Abnormal CTG
  • Contracted pelvis

questions.text: At which angle would you perform a mediolateral episiotomy in a primigravida?
questions.solution:
The mediolateral episiotomy is directed at an angle of 60 degrees. 

The mediolateral episiotomy incision starts in the midline at the fourchette and is directed at an angle 60 degrees from the midline. This 60-degree angle takes into consideration a distortion of perineal anatomy during crowning and ultimately yields an incision that is 45 degrees from the midline following delivery. 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.
